comments.commentBody: John thinking like MTF not thinking like John.  It makes my brain hurt.

Lee Harrison, 25 April post

Dear Dr. Harrison,

"I refute it thus" is Lord Monkton's line, not Lomborg's.

Interesting response. Perhaps her essay (which by the way if you pay attention to detail was for Berkeley and not for Stanford where she is going) it addresses something of who you are? I know Northville a little and quite a few people I know there have reacted pretty favorably to this essay as an accurate portrait of one side of this afflluent suburb. In particular, I would say the author seems to include herself in any criticism and the recklessness she feels to be how her school culture is. I guess as the NYT journalist says, she took some risk of the unthinking reaction of people such as yourself. And the essay in terms of writing style showed considerable talent and an eye for how the world is in all its moral complexity.

Hi Carol,
I'm from Northville and don't care for Miss Meister's essay because IT is reckless and inaccurate in it's depiction of a terrific slice of suburban America. Although affluent, Northville is by no means "the wealthiest" city in Michigan. As per my post, if she wanted to experience life outside of the suburban bubble she could easily have applied to Wayne State University in downtown Detroit instead of Stanford University in Palo Alto, California. Hypocrite comes to mind...kind of like a New Yorker complaining about whining. Hilarious as I have several very good friends in New York. The only whinier city that New York is Boston...just pulling your leg Carol.
I wouldn't know firsthand whether Northville, Michigan, is the snobbiest place in the state but judging by the posts here it would also seem to be in contention for the most whiney and jealous.

As is often the case, the comments are as entertaining as the essays themselves. Especially with regard to Northville High School, the responses kept me laughing, frankly. As a rule, nothing demonstrates better how close the writer has come to being spot on in her observations than the frenzied defensiveness and heated denials made by her fellow students. Most interesting is how the commenters all really failed in a major way to get the point that the essay was about Ms. Meisner, the author, and not about them. And it does what a college essay is supposed to do - represent the student's point of view on the topic on which she chose to write and comment. I think the responses - all heat but little light! - almost do more to prove her point than the essay itself!

Furthermore, to say that any of these students portrayed themselves as "victims" in these essays is grossly unfair to them and shows a real lack of understanding of what a college essay is about. They should all be congratulated on their success - writing a good college essay is no easy thing and a source of major anxiety for many students. Doing a good job is something of which they can all be proud without snarky adults making stupid comments.

comments.userDisplayName: Divorce is Good For American Economy
comments.commentBody: High school student obsession with "college essays", fed by English department and guidance staff even allows PC machinery, here the venerable NYT, to live off the hysteria while pushing the liberal agenda and imposing it on young people and future college educated fellow citizens.

"Competitions" like this "best essays" contest really just exalt these essays into something they're not -- and not supposed to be!

Essays are not free-standing writing competitions, but rather complementary parts (and a relatively small one!) of individuals' colleges applications. An essay is meant to provide a chance for an individual applicant to highlight or explain some aspect of their own broader application 'package'. In no shape or form, do essays 'compete' with each other in the way this contest suggests. (Competition may be among applicants for slots in a given college, but that's between overall applications--grades, tests, recommendations, extracurriculars, etc..)

Fueling exacerbated hoopla about essays (outside the context of applications) is implicitly misinforming the public about the college admissions process, and what matters there (and how essays factor in).

Worse still, this basically fuels the ever-expanding college-consultant rackets, especially those with a focus on essays (who play on applicants' / parents' anxieties about admissions to suggest that these essays play a role they just don't in order to essentially market the 'value' of their 'services')!

This is a real disservice. And one which has helped skew the admissions process at 'competitive' schools from the purposes of selecting applicants (colleges now spent time trying to access if applicants actually wrote their essays! and more fraught for applicants!

And then, of course, there's Bernie Sanders who preaches much the same thing that The Donald's supporters like to imagine that their candidate does. The white working-class has, in fact, been royally screwed but Bernie tells us that the fault lies not with ethnic or racial minorities (who have ALSO been royally screwed) but rather with the "royals" themselves- the patricians, the CEOs, the Donald Trumps!!- who send jobs and companies abroad, hire undocumented aliens, bust unions and purchase Congressional representatives to ensure that they're treated with kids' gloves by the IRS and rack up the profits that the employees they decide to hold on to continue to earn on their behalf.  True enough: not all populists are bigots or xenophobes, and it may well prove necessary for Hillary and some of her supporters to acknowledge- as Bernie has- that the problems of the white working-class are worth devoting some serious time to.  The Donald can't win by appealing exclusively to white men, but Hillary won't win either without reaching out beyond her constituencies of blacks, Latinos and white career-women.

No class privilege is not having these insights. Being unable to put yourself in anyone's else's shoes and actually commenting on an essay you don't seem to have read but instead just project your preconceptions as to what it might be saying but isn't. The maturity of the essay is the author seeing herself as part of the problem.
Yep interesting how perceptive insights bring out the nasty side of those who don't have much to contribute in the way of insights. Well said.
I think you must have read a different essay from me.

Well I guess some kids like me had parents that didn't even graduate from high school and it sure would have helped me to have someone give me some advice and guidance. My school gave me a great education but was not much use at helping with applications: just some tips on what is being sought would have helped a lot.

These four college application essays are WONDERFUL! Fascinating reading, and ripe for discussion. Why not put even more of them on line - the top 100?
Hope you can find room for more of them in the future.
This is great: someone being snobby about Northville not from the Upper East Side or some other upper class Mecca, but from Bloomfield Hills. I guess it's all about the insecurity of pecking order?

The Torah says: we don't see the world as it is but as we are. Many of the negative comments on your piece reflect that wisdom pretty well. I mean come on these are essays by talented 17-18 year olds. Throwing rocks at them seems pretty mean spirited to me. And a good accompanying article and I think good choice of essays.

Why not hire an independent college counselor if the family can afford it?  My daughter's high school had two college counselors - one for last names A - M, and one for last names N - Z.   For a class of over 700.   Tell me, how would you be able to give individual advice to 350 kids?  Really?  You'd be able to tell Ashley that she should apply to University of Nebraska's Agriculture School, but Dwayne should consider Cal Berkeley?
"This one Mexican kid."  And there's no racism at Northfield? There's a pretty well-known saying about glass houses.
You posted this twice with different words.  You're trying a little too hard.

I suppose good insightful writing is supposed to show us things we miss. So perhaps reflect that others may see what you don't or perhaps even that you are part of the problem. The author certainly writes as if she thought she was part of the problem, some of the emptiness she mentions. That is why I found her essay mature. She uses "we" a lot, rather than just suggest it's the  others. And having wanted to escape from a  largely different but also in some respect similiar high school culture, I think her personal testimony to how she feels as part of your school is probably as valid as your take. Maybe more so. I cannot say as I don't know your school.
Erica Meister is not even from Northville.  She lives in Novi... yet she calls Northville her hometown?

Liberals and progressives like nothing more than someone hammering on an affluent suburb.

“I found myself victim to the disease that infiltrates Northville,"
Furthermore she is a victim!

I grew up in the liberal paradise of Detroit and currently live in Northville. Which do I prefer? Well, I have some land in Detroit I'll give to any liberal who will agree to build a house and raise a family there.
...
That's what I thought.

The Northville School District encompasses part of Novi, thus many people who live in Novi have kids in Northville schools. Most such families consider Northville their home because that is where they and their kids get involved in school activities and that, of course, is where their kids' friends live. The area is often called "No-Ville" because it is a blend of the two. That is probably why the essay says something like "the town I CONSIDER to be my hometown...."
That is totally accurate since, as I said, most people conside

Many University of Michigan grads are doing exactly that. 15,000 young college grad newcomers have arrived in Detroit in the last few years. I am sure one of them will take you up on the offer. Indeed the ones I know are farming there so your land would come in handy. I suggest you put up an ad on Facebook or somewhere for your kind offer. Why not post your contact details here so folk can contact you directly?
I am puzzled with Erica Meister's article.  First, Northville is not a super wealthy city.  Second, Erica lives in Novi --- not Northville.  Novi is Erica's hometown.
Erica's hometown is actually Novi -- not Northville.  Right?

I am guessing that many of the essays are expressing serious stress over money; the fact that our rich nation is stingy (parsimonious Puritans) about educating the middle class and poor. The gap between the rich and the rest of us is growing so fast is is getting hard to outraged anymore. Not only do we need socialized medicine, we also need socialized education, just like the rest of the developed world. Socialism is good for many things,even in the USA!

Before my nephew submitted his college essay, my sister asked me to read it and give him feedback. His heartfelt essay was about the lessons he had learned from a fellow student--someone not in his social circle--about friendship. I was easily drawn into a very touching story, but there were a couple of places that didn't seem to fit the tenor of the story. It appeared as if  there were two different writing styles. When I expressed my concern, my sister said her son's school counselor had made the "corrections" I found objectionable and thought detracted from the spirit of the essay. My advice to my nephew was to ignore his counselor's suggestions and to write the entire essay from his heart--just as he had for most of the story. I hope my nephew, who has since graduated from the college of his choice, learned a valuable lesson about trusting his own instincts.

The theme of the last essay was recklessness, so using the word 'careful' was appropriate and, as the last poster said, avoided a cliche ending. She defined 'recklessness' as a lack of concern for others' feelings AND as a lack of concern about consequences. The use of the word 'careful' thus also encompasses both. I thought her use of words was part of what made the essay interesting.

All four essays are terrific!
londoned - Perhaps you are right.  I think I was put off by the distant tone of Ms. Meister's effort.  I couldn't hear a human voice there.  Her choice of 'careful' fits what she has revealed.
Can we collectively lay off it? These are kids, albeit articulate, bright kids, finding their way. A little compassion, perhaps? (How little, you ask?)

It has been interesting to read the comments from Ms. Meister's fellow students. I didn't like her essay and would have been far more interested and impressed if her last line had used the word 'caring' instead of 'careful'. There is a big difference.

Mr. Liggo's essay was so simple and truthful. I think you will do very well, and I hope you make some good friends at Manhattan College, you have a lot to offer.

As an officer of the National Honor Society, you, of all people, should know how students at Northville High School get away with the reckless behavior Ms. Meister described in her essay. It was members of the National Honor Society who cyber-bullied another student last year. http://www.hometownlife.com/story/news/local/northville/2014/10/21/north... The people responsible weren’t expelled -- they weren’t even removed from the National Honor Society. I’m sure their father’s money and connections had nothing to do with the reason most of them weren’t even given a slap on the wrist.
